description: This course explores major aspects of language use that reflect Japanese culture and society. Issues covered include the characteristics of the Japanese language, loan words, regional differences, politeness, gender differences and communication styles. The course will be taught in a combination of lectures, class discussions, subtitled Japanese films, anime (Japanese animation) and student presentations. There are no prerequisites for 126; knowledge of Japanese helpful but not necessary. Readings, lectures and discussions are all in English. The prerequisite for 226 is Japanese 231.
name: Japanese Lang/Society
title: Japenese Language in Society

description: In this Interim course students who have completed the Asian Conversations sequence travel to sites in China and Japan in order to experience those cultures firsthand and to study Chinese and Japanese constructions of national identity. Through readings, site visits, interactions with peers in the target languages, homestays and journal writing in both English and their target language, students learn about how Asians in these two countries perceive themselves and their role in the region and in the world, both in the past and in the present. They travel to Shanghai, Nanjing, Beijing, Nagasaki and Tokyo. Prerequisite: Asian Studies 211 or permission of the instructor.
name: Nat ID/China & Japan
prerequisites: Prerequisite: Asian Studies 211 or permission of the instructor.
title: Asian Conversations: National Identity in China and Japan

description: This course explores major aspects of language use that reflect Japanese culture and society. Issues covered include the characteristics of the Japanese language, loan words, regional differences, politeness, gender differences and communication styles. The course will be taught in a combination of lectures, class discussions, subtitled Japanese films, anime (Japanese animation) and student presentations. There are no prerequisites for 126; knowledge of Japanese helpful but not necessary. Readings, lectures and discussions are all in English. The prerequisite for 226 is Japanese 231.
name: Top: Japan Lang & Soc
title: Japenese Language in Society

description: This course examines issues of women's biology including views of the evolving female and biological determinism. Core material covers anatomy, development, the biological basis of gender, reproduction, sexual response, the menstrual cycle and aging and aspects of women's health such as eating disorders, cancers and hormonal treatments. Students participate in significant amounts of group work and oral presentation. The course is open to both men and women. Offered during Interim. GE: NST-B.
name: The Biology of Women

description: Through lectures, readings and field placements in Minneapolis, students gain an understanding of how race, class, ethnicity, national origin, gender, sexual orientation and religion shape the character of urban youth and communities. Students spend the first week on campus in preparation for their placements and the last week reflecting upon their experiences. During weeks two and three students live in Minneapolis and tutor in the schools and participate in various after-school activities. Counts toward the major: American Racial and Multicultural Studies.
name: Schools & Communities
title: Urban Schools and Communities

description: Students examine the influence of race, class and multiculturalism in American schools by participating as teachers' assistants and tutors in two distinctly different K-12 settings. Through guest lectures, readings, field trips and seminars, students explore the unique geography and culture of the Hawaiian Islands and develop a framework for examining diversity on the mainland. Prerequisite: Education 290, 2.7 GPA, meeting all off-campus study requirements and satisfactory portfolio progress. Fulfills Education 382 and partially fulfills clinical practicum requirements. Students apply in the Spring Semester. Counts toward the major: American Racial and Multicultural Studies.
name: Multi-Cult Ed Hawaii
prerequisites: Prerequisite: Education 290, 2.7 GPA, meeting all off-campus study requirements and satisfactory portfolio progress. Fulfills Education 382 and partially fulfills clinical practicum requirements. Students apply in the Spring Semester. Counts toward the major: American Racial and Multicultural Studies.
title: Multicultural Education in Hawaii: Seminar and Practicum

description: Students explore the Greek and Hebrew legacies in Roman society and in the New Testament, discussing various attempts to find personal fulfillment in political life, in stoicism and epicureanism and in the teachings of Christ and St. Paul. Students read works by Cicero, Horace, Virgil, Epictetus, the writers of the New Testament and study the artistry of Roman sculpture. Offered only in Interim.
name: Romans & Christians
title: The Tradition Continuing: The Romans and the Christians

description: This course traces the influences of religion in Rome as it was gradually transformed from the capital city of a pagan empire into the administrative center of Catholic Christianity. Students conduct a selective comparison of ancient, medieval, renaissance, baroque and modern religion through visits to historical sites, churches, museums and contemporary cultural events in Rome -- and to other Italian cities which interacted with Rome. Offered in Interim, 2001-02.
name: Religion/Culture/Rome
title: Religion and Culture in Rome

description: The nature and boundaries of communities, as well as the quality of relationships within communities, are determined by theology as well as by social, political and ethnic factors. Students examine the ways in which the world's religions, particularly Christianity, have interpreted each other's significance and truth claims and considers the ethical implications of these different responses. Prerequisite: a BTS-T course.
name: Rel Pluralsm/Communit
title: Religious Pluralism and the Nature of Community

description: This course compares gender patterns and issues in various cultures around the world, such as Latin America, the Middle East, India, the U.S. and East Asia. How do cultural expectations for women and men vary? Why do some societies have more gender equality than others? How do economic and political change, including globalization, impact gender roles? How do U.S. and Third World feminism compare? Offered Fall Semester.
name: Gender/C-Cult/Persp
title: Gender in Cross-Cultural Perspective

description: Through exploring the geographic and human diversity of the Spanish-speaking world, students develop increasingly complex skills for analyzing and communicating in Spanish. They study such essential dimensions of that world as: (1) geography and development; (2) environmental challenges and solutions; (3) population and demographic changes and challenges; and (4) ethnic diversity. Prerequisite: Spanish 112 or placement. Offered Fall and Spring Semesters.
name: Intermed Spanish I
prerequisites: Prerequisite: Spanish 112 or placement. Offered Fall and Spring Semesters.
title: Intermediate Spanish I

description: Students explore geographic, economic, political and ethnic dimensions of life in present-day Ecuador by combining intensive course work with such cross-cultural experiences as a homestay in Quito, interactions with university students in Quito, field trips to an indigenous maket in Otavalo, the Amazon region east of Tena, and so forth. They consolidate their language skills and continue to develop their skills for analyzing and communicating in Spanish by writing compositions, making oral presentations, interviewing their host families, visiting indigenous homes and engaging in other interactive group activities. Prerequisite: Spanish 231 or placement.
name: Inter Span II-Ecuador
title: Intermediate Spanish II in Ecuador

description: Students explore geographic, economic, political and ethnic dimensions of life in present-day Costa Rica by combining intensive course work with such cross-cultural experiences as a homestay in San Jose; field work, visits to sites of cultural interest and excursions to the geographically and culturally diverse Atlantic and Pacific coasts. They consolidate their language skills and continue to develop their skills for analyzing and communicating in Spanish by writing compositions, making oral presentations, interviewing their host families and engaging in other interactive group activities. Prerequisite: Spanish 231 or placement.
name: Inter Span II-C Rica
title: Intermediate Spanish II in Costa Rica

description: Students reflect on their own culture as they explore childhood and family life in China and Japan. Developmental and cross-cultural research, memoirs, works of fiction, and films are used to study parents' beliefs and childrearing practices as well as the development of the self, peer relationships, school achievement, and role changes during adulthood. With life expectancy increasing around the world, students also discover how China and Japan are responding to the graying of their populations. Prerequisites: Psychology 125 or Asian Studies 111 or Asian Studies 121.
name: Human Dev/China and Japan
prerequisites: Prerequisites: Psychology 125 or Asian Studies 111 or Asian Studies 121.
title: Human Development in East Asia: Perspectives from China and Japan
